docs.title: Termynal
docs.text: A lightweight and modern animated terminal window. Built for mkdocs.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: pip install termynalInstalled

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Use <!-- termynal --> before code block

```
// code
```
// code

docs.title: progress
docs.text:
progress, prompt ---> 100%

```
$ show progress
---> 100%
Done!
```
show progressDone!

docs.title: command
docs.text:
command, start with $. You can change it with prompt_literal_start option.

```
$ python
>>> import requests
>>> requests.get('https://exampls.com')
<Response [200]>
>>>
```
pythonimport requestsrequests.get('https://exampls.com')<Response [200]>>>>

docs.title: multiline command
docs.text:
```
> some longish command with \
  many \
    many \
      many \
  arguments
and this is the output
```
some longish command with \ many \ many \ many \ argumentsand this is the output

docs.title: comment
docs.text:
comment, start with #

```
# comment
```
# comment

docs.title: output
docs.text:
tool's help looks like this:

```
$ poetry --help

...
```
poetry --helpDescription: Lists commands.Usage: list [options] [--] [<namespace>]Arguments: namespace The namespace nameOptions: -h, --help Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command. -q, --quiet Do not output any message. -V, --version Display this application version. --ansi Force ANSI output. --no-ansi Disable ANSI output. -n, --no-interaction Do not ask any interactive question. --no-plugins Disables plugins. --no-cache Disables Poetry source caches. -C, --directory=DIRECTORY The working directory for the Poetry command (defaults to the current working directory). -v|vv|vvv, --verbose Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug.Help: The list command lists all commands: poetry list You can also display the commands for a specific namespace: poetry list test

docs.title: Mkdocs integration
docs.text:
Declare the plugin:

...
plugins:
  - termynal
...

Optionally, pass options to the processor:

[...]
plugins:
  - termynal:
      prompt_literal_start:
        - "$"
        - ">"
[...]

This config allows you to use another prompt:

```
> command with >
Ok!
```
command with >Ok!

docs.title: Changelog
docs.text:
All notable changes to this project will be documented in this file.

The format is based on Keep a Changelog and this project adheres to Semantic Versioning.

docs.text: • you can override configs for each block

docs.text: • lang console doesn't work more, use termynal comment string in md

docs.text: • fix multiline output, it works without animation

docs.title: Fix
docs.text: • fix typing

docs.text: • can change a termynal title via settings

docs.title: Feat
docs.text: • set white-space to pre for span line

docs.title: Refactor
docs.text:
• simplify code
  • add type hintings

docs.title: Feat
docs.text: • fix cmd animation in multiline commands

docs.title: Feat
docs.text: • make the processor configurable to customize termynal.js behavior (#6)

docs.title: Fix
docs.text: • check content type to avoid processing errors (#5)

docs.title: Feat
docs.text: • add "restart" and "faster" button to animation in termynal

docs.title: Refactor

docs.title: Other
docs.text: • Use mkdocs ^1.4

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Added <!-- termynal -->
  • Added console => class="language-console"

docs.title: v0.1.0 - 2020-11-14
docs.text: • init

docs.title: Code of Conduct
docs.text: This project adheres to the Python Code of Conduct, which can be found here.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
name default title "bash" buttons "macos" "macos", "windows" prompt_literal_start ["$"] 
plugins:
  - termynal:
      title: bash
      buttons: macos
      prompt_literal_start:
        - "$"

You can override configurations for each block. If you set a part of the settings, the other part will be set to the default value.

<!-- termynal: {"prompt_literal_start": ["$", ">>>", "PS >"], title: powershell, buttons: windows} -->

```
PS > python
>>> import json
```
pythonimport json

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
When contributing to this repository, please first discuss the change you wish to make via issue, email, or any other method with the owners of this repository before making a change.

Welcome! Happy to see you willing to make the project better.

docs.title: Install
docs.text:
Install poetry

make install-poetry
# pip install poetry
  • don't forget to use the last version of poetry
  • don't forget to write a code for python 3.8+
  • don't forget to use virtualenv
  • For using venv in the project directory, run poetry config virtualenvs.in-project true

Install dependencies

make install

docs.title: Run tests
docs.text:
Please, write tests for your code.

make test

docs.title: Formatting
docs.text:
Autofix code style issues.

make format

docs.title: Lint
docs.text:
Check code style issues.

make lint

docs.title: Release
docs.text:
Automatically after merging with the master.

  1. make bump
  2. git push and git push --tags

docs.title: Commit Message Format
docs.text: This project adheres to Conventional Commits. A specification for adding human and machine readable meaning to commit messages.

docs.title: Commit Message Header
docs.text:
<type>(<scope>): <short summary>
  │       │             │
  │       │             └─⫸ Summary in present tense. Not capitalized. No period at the end.
  │       │
  │       └─⫸ Commit Scope
  │
  └─⫸ Commit Type: feat|fix|build|ci|docs|perf|refactor|test|chore

docs.title: Type
docs.text: type name description feat Features A new feature fix Bug Fixes A bug fix docs Documentation Documentation only changes style Styles Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code (white-space, formatting, missing semi-colons, etc) refactor Code Refactoring A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a feature perf Performance Improvements A code change that improves performance test Tests Adding missing tests or correcting existing tests build Builds Changes that affect the build system or external dependencies (example scopes: mypy, pip, pytest) ci Continuous Integrations Changes to our CI configuration files and scripts (example scopes: Github Actions) chore Chores Other changes that don't modify src or test files revert Reverts Reverts a previous commit
